ala.definition: no, not, zero; [~ ala ~] (used to form a yes-no question)

alasa.definition: to hunt, forage | ALT (pv.) to seek, try to, attempt

ale, ali.definition: all; abundant, countless, bountiful, every, plentiful; abundance, everything, life, universe; one hundred | ALT twenty; 100; 120

alu.definition: (between the main sentence and the context phrase)

anpa.definition: bowing down, downward, humble, lowly, dependent

awen.definition: enduring, kept, protected, safe, waiting, staying; to continue to
awen.etymology: houden ‘keep, care for, hold (in a particular state)’

en.definition: (between multiple subjects) | ALT (coordinates modifiers in a pi-phrase or objects of a prepostion)

esun.definition: market, shop, fair, bazaar, business transaction

ete.definition: beyond, exceeding, outside of, more than

ike.definition: bad, negative; non-essential, irrelevant | ALT complicated, complex

ilo.etymology:
ilo ‘tool’ ← German -el ‘(agent suffix)’ {cf. Schlüssel ‘key’ ~
schließen ‘lock, shut’)

insa.definition: centre, content, inside, between; internal organ, stomach

ipi.definition: (presented as an early alternative to iki) {see ona}

isipin.definition: to think, to imagine, to believe

itomi.definition: Schadenfreude, indirect insult or disrespect, shade
itomi.etymology: hit or miss (from the song ‘Mia Khalifa’ by iLOVEFRiDay)

jaki.definition: disgusting, obscene, sickly, toxic, unclean, unsanitary

jalan.definition: foot {see noka} | ALT walk, go by foot

jami.definition: eliciting a positive sensory or stimulating experience {see suwi}

jasima.definition: reflect, resound, mirror, be on the opposite/polar end of

jo.definition: to have, carry, contain, hold {see lon, poki, lanpan}

kalama.definition: to produce a sound; recite, utter aloud

kama.definition: arriving, coming, future, summoned; (pv.) to become, manage to, succeed in
kama.etymology: kamap ‘event, arrive, happen, become, bring about, summon’ ← English come up

kan.etymology: Finnish kanssa ‘with’ or Esperanto kun ‘with’ (← Latin cum)

kapa.definition: extrusion, protrusion, hill, mountain, button {see nena}
kapa.etymology: Dutch kop ‘head, cup’ or Esperanto kapo ‘head’ (← Latin caput)

kapesi.etymology: Georgian ყავისფერი q̇avisperi ‘brown’ or French/Spanish café ‘light brown’

ken.definition: to be able to, be allowed to, can, may; possible

kepeken.definition: to use, with, by means of

kijetesantakalu.definition:
any animal from the Procyonidae
family, such as raccoons, coatis, kinkajous, olingos, ringtails and cacomistles

kin.definition: {see a} | ALT indeed, too, also, as well

kipisi.etymology: Iñupiat kipriruk ‘cut’ or Swahili kipisi ‘sliver, small piece of wood’

ko.definition: clay, clinging form, dough, semi-solid, paste, powder

kokosila.definition: to speak a non-Toki Pona language in an environment where Toki Pona is more appropriate
kokosila.etymology:
krokodilas ‘[present of krokodili] to speak among
Esperantists in a language besides Esperanto’ ← krokodilo ‘crocodile’

kon.definition: air, breath; essence, spirit; hidden reality, unseen agent
kon.etymology: 空氣 kōngqì ‘air, atmosphere, ambience, opinion’

kule.definition: colorful, pigmented, painted | ALT of or relating to the LGBT+ community

kulu.definition: {shortened variant of kulupu}; six {particulary in senary base}

kulupu.definition: community, company, group, nation, society, tribe

kute.definition: ear; to hear, listen; pay attention to, obey

la.definition: (between the context phrase and the main sentence)
la.etymology: Esperanto la ‘(definite article)’ (← Romance la ‘(feminine singular definite article)’) or Acadian French -la ‘(proximal & topical suffix)’

lanpan.definition: take, seize, catch, receive, get {see jo, alasa}

lawa.definition: head, mind; to control, direct, guide, lead, own, plan, regulate, rule

leko.etymology: English Lego (← Danish Lego ← ‘leg godt’ ‘play well’) or Finnish lohko ‘block, section’

len.definition: cloth, clothing, fabric, textile; cover, layer of privacy

li.definition: (between any subject except mi alone or sina alone and its verb; also to introduce a new verb for the same subject)
li.etymology: li ‘he’ ← Latin ille {cf. Tok Pisin i ← English he}

likujo.definition: collection, assortment, menagerie, arrangement, handful, harvest {see kulupu, alasa}; seven

lili.definition: little, small, short; few; a bit; young

linja.definition: long and flexible thing; cord, hair, rope, thread, yarn | ALT line, connection

lipu.definition: flat object; book, document, card, paper, record, website

lon.definition: located at, present at, real, true, existing | ALT (affirmative response)
lon.etymology: long ‘at, in, on, (spacial particle)’ ← English along

luka.definition: arm, hand, tactile organ; five | ALT touch/feel physically, interact, press

lukin.definition: eye {see oko}; look at, see, examine, observe, read, watch; (pv.) to seek, look for, try to {see alasa}
lukin.etymology:
lukim ‘see, look at’ ← luk ‘look’ (← English look) + -im
‘(transitive suffix)’ (← English him, ’em)

lupa.etymology: clupa ‘loop’ (← Mandarin 圈 quān, English loop, Hindi पाश pāś, Arabic أنشوطة‏ ʾanšūṭa)

ma.definition: earth, land; outdoors, world; country, territory; soil

majuna.etymology: maljuna ‘old’ ← mal- ‘(opposite of)’ (← Latin malus ‘bad’) + juna ‘young’ (← German jung & French jeune)

mama.definition: parent, ancestor; creator, originator; caretaker, sustainer

mani.definition: money, cash, savings, wealth; large domesticated animal
mani.etymology: money {cf. fee ← Proto-Germanic *fehu ‘livestock’, and pecuniary ← Latin pecū ‘cattle’}

meli.definition: woman, female, feminine person; wife {see mije, tonsi}
meli.etymology:
meri ‘woman, wife, feminine’ ← Tolai mari ‘pretty’ & 
English Mary

mi.etymology: mi ‘I, me’ ← Romance m- ‘(1st person singular oblique)’

mije.definition: man, male, masculine person; husband {see meli, tonsi}

moku.definition: to eat, drink, consume, swallow, ingest

monsuta.etymology: モンスター monsutā ‘monster’ ← English monster

mun.definition: moon, night sky object, star | ALT glow, glowing light, light in the dark {see suno}

mute.definition: many, a lot, more, much, several, very; quantity | ALT three (or more)

n.definition: [interjection] indicating thinking, pondering, or recognition; hum, humming

namako.definition: {see sin} | ALT embellishment, spice; extra additional
namako.etymology: Hindi नमक namak ‘salt’ (← Persian نمک namak ‘salt) or Persian نمک namak ‘salt’

nasa.definition: unusual, strange; foolish, crazy; drunk, intoxicated

nasin.definition: way, custom, doctrine, method, path, road

nena.definition: bump, button, hill, mountain, nose, protuberance {see kapa}

noka.definition: foot, leg, organ of locomotion; bottom, lower part {see jalan} | ALT ten; twenty; negate five

o.definition: hey! O! (vocative, imperative, or optative) {see li}

oko.definition: {see lukin} | ALT eye, ocular, visual {cf. lukin}

olin.definition: love, have compassion for, respect, show affection to

omekapo.definition: goodbye, farewell, see you later, eat a good fish
omekapo.etymology: o.m.e.ka.po. ← o moku e kala pona ← coined by jan Maliku in reference to the message jan Sonja wrote on their copy of Toki Pona: The Language of Good during a Texas meetup

omen.etymology: o.m.e.m. ← o moli e mi {cf. English kill me}

ona.definition: he, she, it, they {see iki, ipi}

pakala.definition: botched, broken, damaged, harmed, messed up | ALT (curse expletive, e.g. fuck!)

pali.definition: do, take action on, work on; build, make, prepare
pali.etymology: fari ‘do, make’ ← Italian fare & Acadian French faire

palisa.definition: long hard thing; branch, rod, stick

pan.definition: cereal, grain; barley, corn, oat, rice, wheat; bread, pasta
pan.etymology: Romance pan ‘bread’ & Japanese パン pan (← Portuguese pão)

pana.definition: give, send, emit, provide, put, release
pana.etymology: Finnish panna ‘put, set, place’ or Swahili pana ‘give to each other’

pasila.definition: good, easy {see pona}; simple, relaxed, peaceful, uncomplicated

pata.etymology: Serbo-Croatian brat брат ‘brother’ or Tok Pisin brata ‘sibling or cousin of the same gender’ (← English brother)

pi.definition: of (used to divide a second noun group that describes a first noun group) | ALT (introduces a genitive noun)

pilin.definition: heart (physical or emotional); feeling (an emotion, a direct experience)
pilin.etymology: pilim ‘feel’ ← pil ‘feel’ (← English feel) + -im ‘(transitive suffix)’ (← English him, ’em)

pini.definition: ago, completed, ended, finished, past {see pake}
pini.etymology: Acadian French fini ‘finished, completed’ & Tok Pisin pinis ‘(perfective aspect)’← English finish

poka.definition: hip, side; next to, nearby, vicinity | ALT along with (comitative), beside {see kan}
poka.etymology: boka бока, genitive of bok бок ‘side, flank’

poki.definition: container, bag, bowl, box, cup, cupboard, drawer, vessel

pomotolo.etymology: pomodoro ‘tomato,’ from the time management method developed by Francesco Cirillo in Berlin in the 1980s, for which people often used tomato-shaped timers

pona.definition: good, positive, useful; friendly, peaceful; simple

powe.definition: unreal, false, untrue, pretend, deceive, trickster

pu.definition: interacting with the official Toki Pona book
pu.etymology: Mandarin 樸 pǔ ‘unworked wood; inherent quality; simple’ or English book

sama.definition: same, similar; each other; sibling, peer, fellow {see pata}; as, like
sama.etymology: Finnish sama ‘same’ (← Proto-Germanic *samaz ‘same, alike’) & Esperanto sama ‘same’ (← English same)

samu.etymology: jan Samu, a Facebook user who attempted to propose a new word

san.definition: three {particularly in senary base; see tuli};

seli.definition: fire; cooking element, chemical reaction, heat source

selo.definition: outer form, outer layer; bark, peel, shell, skin; boundary
selo.etymology: ŝelo ‘skin, peel’ ← German Schale ‘peel, husk, shell’

sewi.definition: area above, highest part, something elevated; awe-inspiring, divine, sacred, supernatural

sijelo.definition: body (of person or animal), physical state, torso

sike.definition: round or circular thing; ball, circle, cycle; of one year

sikomo.definition: on a higher tier/plane, enlighten(ed), epic; to an exceedingly great extent
sikomo.etymology: sicko mode (← Travis Scott song ‘Sicko Mode’)

sin.definition: new, fresh; additional, another, extra {see namako}

sitelen.definition: image, picture, representation, symbol, mark, writing

sona.definition: know, be skilled in, be wise about, have information on; (pv.) know how to

su.definition: [yes/no question marker, taking the place of li & o] {see ala}

suli.definition: big, heavy, large, long, tall; important; adult

suno.definition: sun; light, brightness, glow {see mun}, radiance, shine; light source

supa.definition: horizontal surface, thing to put or rest something on

sutopatikuna.etymology: čudnovati kljunaš ‘platypus, lit. strange beak’ (proposed by Alexandre Baudry)

tan.definition: by, from, because of; origin, cause

taso.etymology: tasol ‘just, only, but, however’ ← English that’s all

tawa.definition: going to, toward; for; from the perspective of; moving | ALT (pv.) going to

telo.definition: water, liquid, fluid, wet substance; beverages

tenpo.definition: time, duration, moment, occasion, period, situation {see waleja}

tokana.definition: focus, attention, concentrate, resolution, fineness; focus on

toki.definition: communicate, say, speak, talk, use language, think; hello

tomo.definition: indoor space; building, home, house, room
tomo.etymology: domo ‘house’ ← Polish dom, Latin domus, Ancient Greek δόμος

tonsi.definition: non-binary, gender-non-conforming {see meli, mije, kule} | ALT trans, non-cisgender

unpa.definition: have sexual or marital relations with

utala.definition: battle, challenge, compete against, struggle against

waleja.definition: context, topic, salience, pertinent, topical, pertain to, be relevant {see tenpo}
waleja.etymology: valdea ‘of moment, important’ ← valda ‘worth, worthy, dear’

wawa.definition: strong, powerful; confident, sure; energetic, intense

wawajete.definition: something that appears to break the rules but doesn't; faux edginess, provocation
wawajete.etymology:
wuwojiti (all phonotactically unviable CV syllables in 
toki pona)

we.definition: (acts as a transition from one complete sentence to another)

wekama.definition: leave and come back, be temporarily absent with the expectation of returning

wile.definition: must, need, require, should, want, wish

yupekosi.definition: to behave like George Lucas and revise your old creative works and actually make them worse; “nobody knows how to pronounce the y”
